author: aquariusfz53
title: Excellent service
body: Service was excellent and friendly

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: chachatt77
title: The midwives are truly superb!
body:
The care I have received during my stay on Daisy Hill Hospital's Maternity Ward has been unbelievably good. I really cannot speak highly enough of the midwives who have looked after me. They are truly superb - I honestly cannot use words to explain how good they have been. They are all extremely friendly and their communication has been amazing - they explain everything so carefully and in an understandable manner. They really are like a little family - well done to you all!  
The ward itself is absolutely brilliant - I really cannot fault it. All the staff are absolutely on the ball when it comes to keeping the ward very clean and tidy. They truly are attentive to every detail!  
There has honestly been not a thing wrong with my stay here on Maternity - the only thing I would like to see is that the midwives should all get paid more for the absolutely phenomenal work they are doing!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: claire26
title: Excellent care received
body: I had to attend the Day assessment unit to be assessed due to concerns I had over my baby's movements. I can't praise all the midwifes and doctors I saw enough, they were all very kind and helpful. They all made me feel very relaxed and calm. I can't thank them enough for the care I received today, especially with the current situation ongoing within the hospital.

author: authenticcw47
title: A very good maternity experience
body:
My maternity experience at Daisy Hill has been really very good. All the midwives are incredibly nice and very lovely. They really can't do enough for you - always there whenever you need them for anything. They really are just so very helpful.  
The maternity ward itself is very good with everything you need close by where you need it, e.g. toilets only a few metres away. Just very handy and accessible.  
My stay has just been so very good - nothing could have been any better. Just keep up all the great work everybody!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: jupiterxm58
title: Staff have been absolutely unreal
body:
My time in the maternity ward at Daisy Hill Hospital has been absolutely super. All the staff involved in my care have been absolutely unreal. The midwives are all brilliant - they really could not do enough for you - they are all very helpful, caring and kind.  
I have also been very happy with the ward itself - it is absolutely lovely. The staff always ensure the ward is completely spotless - incredibly clean. As well as that the food has all been absolutely lovely throughout my stay - so well done to all the staff involved in these areas.  
There are no real improvements that I could suggest - my stay and care has been nothing but excellent and I am overall very happy with my time here on maternity. Keep up the good work!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: jackpotkq87
title: Nurses are 100% dead on!
body: My time on the female surgical ward at Daisy Hill Hospital has been alright. I came in due to having difficulty swallowing and the staff have all treated me very well.   The nurses are all very lovely - really very nice and dead on. They really are just 100%! The ward itself has been nice enough and I have no real complaints. Although my stay has been a good one I hope I'm not back in again anytime soon!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: giftss78
title: Staff are absolutely first class
body:
Over the past while I have been in and out of Daisy Hill Hospital like a yo-yo and my current experience has been good - as it usually is.  
My current visit began in the Emergency Department which went very well. I was seen to relatively quickly and was very well looked after. As always, the staff were brilliant - absolutely first class as usual.  
I was then moved up on to the female surgical ward. My time here has been alright. The nurses have all been fantastic and have cared and looked after me brilliantly - once again a first class - they really couldn't do any better. I have no suggestions which could make my stay any better - it has been an all-round positive experience.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Fobbedoff
title: Told that I need to be re-referred by a doctor
body:
This department seems to have thrown all their patients off their lists during Coronavirus and I have been told that I need to be re-referred by a doctor, why do I need to waste my time going to tell a doctor something they already know and referred me for in the first place, I have a chronic pain condition, note the word chronic, it can’t be cured therefore has to be managed and right now it’s not being managed because I haven’t seen anyone in over a year or had any pain treatment! this is not good enough, peoples pain and chronic illnesses did not disappear when Coronavirus started.  
I’m beyond fed up, this is having a detrimental impact on my mental health and other heath conditions, the stress and misery, I have very little fight in me yet I have to fight for healthcare, why does it have to be this way? If I went to a vet with an animal in chronic pain, they would say it is inhumane to leave an animal that way, so why is it ok for you to leave humans that way for over a year? no one cares, it’s a very sad state of affairs.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Fobbedoff
title: Doctors surgery
body: Feel like I am in limbo with my doctors surgery, very little care or understanding shown, no empathy, feels like I am talking to a robot that I can’t get through to. I have issues with 3 Heath conditions that need addressed/action taken on and I don’t know where to turn because I feel like I am getting nowhere lax Having chronic health conditions and no consistency with doctors does not help, seems like there’s no doctors at this surgery? any communication with these people plunges me into deeper despair, worsening of my mental health and exacerbation of my chronic pain conditions, I need help

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: wheelchairstuntpilot
title: Another great experience at Ward 20 Day Unit
body: Attended for osteoporosis treatment - Zolendronic Acid infusion. Simple procedure, arrived on time, treated immediately, in and out in an hour or so. Room was scrupulously clean, Stacey and her colleague were super friendly, cheerful and professional; reassuring and kind, a real credit to their profession. Anther great experience at the Freeman Hospital. So proud of the people at the front line of the NHS.

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Sean B
title: Admitted with covid
body: Unbelievable staff in medical assessment unit causeway hospital. Especially nursing assistants Francis, Suzanne, Chris, clinic sister Cathy, and Patricia the ward manager. I have been looked after to the highest level absolutely blown away by everyone. Highly recommended.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Annie 2020
title: Unnecessary delay
body:
Contacted by my practice nurse ask to make an a appointment for repeat blood test due to a slight reduction in kidney function  
Tried to do this via the GG&C phlebotomy hub number supplied by practice nurse  
After three days of trying to access the service I am still unable to make an appointment  
Hub number dialled at least 10 time daily holding on for between 15 and 30mins each time .  
I believe this is an unacceptable level of service and has caused an unnecessary level of delay in me have my blood test performed

readBy.name: Office of John Mason, MSP for Glasgow Shettleston

author: Will53
title: I was referred to have an X-ray on my thumb
body: I had the X-ray and was told to go to A and E to have a screw removed that was starting to push out from a plate at   the base of my thumb I queued for about half an hour to get to the desk then was sent out to Springfield urgent treatment centre I checked in their and sent in to the waiting room where I waited for over two hours then when I was seen I was told I shouldn’t have been sent their I should’ve been sent to the fracture clinic and sent home to wait for another appointment so still getting stabbed by this screw in my thumb.

title: Thank you to the OT falls team
body:
A big thank you to the Occupational falls team at Burnham on sea hospital. The occupational assistant has been so helpful in making my life safer and giving me many exercises and tips. She has also made sure I have the right equipment to help my quality of life.
Thank you

title: Excellent Practice
body: I have been a patient at this surgery for over 25yrs and have always had an excellent experience and relationship with staff and doctors I have a complicated condition and have always felt supported

author: waterkp53
title: Virtual calls with my mother
body: My 92 year old mum is currently in Craigavon Hospital recovering from a fall. As you are aware visiting in Craigavon is currently suspended due to Covid 19. A as result we have been using the virtual call service on a daily basis to speak to my mum. This new service is absolutely fantastic and has enabled our family to speak with mum on a daily basis and has without doubt aided her general wellbeing. I feel that this service should be made a permanent feature of hospital life as it is not always possible to visit a patient in person. Many thanks

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Could Not Fault This Place
body:
I called the hospital 18-08-2021 as I needed stitches removing from a wound in my leg from an accident abroad.
From the person who took my phone call, the lady(and she was a lady) on reception and the two nurses in the Minor Injuries Unit I was treated with kindness and the utmost professionalism, I could not have struck more lucky in my choice of location for treatment.
These people are the best, please give them my thanks.

author: Ju ju
title: Xray results
body: Attended North Tees Hospital for a xray on my extremely painful shoulder. Was told the results would be back in a week. It's now been a month and still no results, have been told they have a backlog of Xrays to be looked at. Almost four weeks and still waiting in pain for results. I have complained to PALS but it was pointless! Now on very strong pain medication, this situation is unacceptable. Needs addressing urgently!

author: Ken F
title: The value of physical activity post chemotherapy and surgery
body:
Joe, now that my course of fitness sessions has finished, I would just like to say how much I enjoyed them and how beneficial I found them to be.  
  
I have always tried to keep myself reasonably active through walking and occasional cycling and when I had my chemotherapy and surgery earlier this year, I believe this stood me in good stead. Where your course proved beneficial, however, was through the stretching and mobility exercises which brought into play muscles which would not normally be in use. These, together with your emphasis on posture, I found particularly valuable.  
  
Again, many thanks for the time and effort you put into the sessions.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: swinggt56
title: Heartfelt thanks for surgical
body:
I was admitted from my doctor to surgical ambulatory care unit near ward 9, when I went there I was seen very quickly and efficiently. I was made feel at ease and was explained everything very clearly about waiting time and what would happen next.  
Nothing was an issue to staff they were very busy on my arrival, they seated me in a room with 4 beds and returned to do bloods and observations this was all done in 10 minutes of arrival this is a very efficient and effective service for the hospital, I was in and seen within about 3 hour and returned next day for an scan which again was booked and ran very timely.  
Only to discover I needed an operation after being scanned. I would very much like to give my thanks for the support they showed me in this area. The support shown to my wife from the nurses ( sorry if I get the names wrong) Leah, Iona and Rachel was outstanding they made her tea and gave her something to eat she was is a diabetic and hadn't eating anything because she was worrying about me, Iona also made sure my wife got home safely by calling our daughter and walking her to the carpark and calling to keep my family updated on my time in there due to no visiting. I cannot thank the nurses enough and in debt I will always be to them. This service is a credit to the NHS and I hope it long may continue, I hope other hospitals follow on from this unit.  
I was admitted to ward 13 where I got excellent care from I was admitted till discharged, the staff were friendly and helpful they spoke me through my drain and the after care I would receive from them and the weeks after. I cannot thank ( again sorry if I get the names mixed up there was so many nurses) Suzanne, Megan and Rosie enough they were fantastic thank you girls. I was in a room of 4 again and the other men also spoke about how great the surgical wards are and how grateful we all are for the care that was showing to us all at the time we needed it the most. Only issue was no bacon on the breakfast menu but we can deal with that.  
Following on from this I had to go back to surgical ambulatory care the following week in fact for several weeks I had attended the clinic and all I can say is it's a fantastic service. I get there about 8-9 and out for lunch, the girls always were welcoming and always smiling. We all know they are doing a fantastic job and keep up the superb work in this area, I was reading the posters based on statistics through the unit and all I can say is a huge well done.  
Take care girls and I wish not to see you again in these circumstances but I will never be able to thank you enough.  
All the best the grumpy auld yin as the wife told you all.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Nodens
title: Therapy success!
body:
During a period in my life where I was experiencing depressive symptoms, my GP prescribed me Setraline. I had a bad reaction to the medication, which caused me to have a breakdown. This was during a tumultuous period in my life so the medication was not solely to blame. Traumatic memories bubbled to the surface and I broke down crying in the GPs office. As a result of this breakdown, I was referred to psychiatry to be treated for PTSD. The sad part was that, due to the trauma specialist leaving, I had an incredibly long wait (18 months) to be seen for treatment. However, when I did begin treatment, I met a nurse who changed my life. I will refer to them as K.  
In the initial meeting with K, we both agreed that therapy was a collaborative project, one which was based on trust and respect. It was through these concepts that I was able to build confidence within the therapy and K themselves. My trauma was not something we immediately tackled. First, we needed to work on the basics. This included help with managing my sleep, appetite, exercise and general physical health. Following this, K and I shifted the focus onto the psychological elements. This included building my self esteem and challenging negative thoughts. Admittedly, during these sessions, I did sometimes wonder why we were not ‘fixing’ my trauma. However, by going through all these exercises and doing the work, I realised I was gaining confidence and calmness within myself. It was only then that K and I agreed I was ready to begin using a technique called EMDR. EMDR is a specific technique which is used to treat trauma. It works by regressing a person into their trauma and, through a combination of lights, eye movement and guided talk, will desensitize an individual to the past experience. This is a lengthy process and can only really be done with a person who is in a stable(ish) mental state and who is willing to engage with the therapist. The only reason I was able to do it is because K was able to instil a sense of safety and trust in them. Otherwise, I would have not felt comfortable or confident enough to do so. I was in therapy with K for 2.5 years, and I have recently been discharged. I am writing this as a way to say thank you to them, as without them, I do not think I would be alive to write this entry. Furthermore, I wanted this to be a way for other people to understand that it is worth the wait and not to give up. I am thankful for the NHS, and the people who work within it, who change other peoples lives for the better.

author: Cherry63
title: Biopsy/hysteroscopy
body:
I am 8 years post surgical menopause. Two weeks ago I had a small PV bleed. My GP referred me to Gynae under the 2 week cancer pathway.  
I suffer from vaginal atrophy, bladder prolapse and a variocele. Internal examinations are excruciating.  
I had a pelvic plus internal scan a week after referral.  
Mid August, I saw a gynae consultant, went through some medical history, and explained my problems with pain. Even smear tests are incredibly painful.  
I was offered a biopsy there and then. I had a panic attack, crying and hyperventilating. I asked for local anaesthetic and was told no, they can't give any injections here. I was offered the choice to return later the week if I needed time to think about it, but I said just do it as I didn't want to be worrying about it.  
The pain was absolutely excruciating and the biopsy was unsuccessful. Only then was I told I could come back and have a local. I don't think the Dr was rough, it was my problem.  
That night I couldn't sleep, I was emotionally and physically traumatised, and very weepy the next day.  
Two days afterwards I was back again, saw a different consultant, explained it all again.  
I had taken paracetamol, maloxicam and diazapam before attending.  
Firstly the speculum was very painful, so the consultant replaced it with a smaller one (why not use the smaller one to start with?). The injection wasn't too bad, but it didn't have time to work before the procedure started.  
The procedure was not explained to me, I was expecting a pipelle biopsy, not a hysteroscopy, and was taken completely unawares when they started pumping water into me. I was yelling, crying and shaking with pain, but they didn't stop until the nurse told her to.  
I only had time to dress, before I was handed the referral paperwork to hand in at reception.  
I have now been referred for the procedure under a GA but have been told it's a long waiting list.  
I'm absolutely furious, I said prior to the procedure that I felt very strongly that as a woman, I know my body, I know how much it would hurt, and that I should have been told at the 1st appointment that I could have been booked in for the local.  
I was very vocal about my fears, and feel that a GA should be available as a first choice for women with problems.  
I questioned why a colonoscopy (I've had a few) is done with IV sedation and pain relief but that wasn't an option. I just got a blank stare.  
I have previously worked in maternity in a different trust, and the ethos was very much women being made to feel empowered, given the chance to make informed choices with their care.

readBy.name: Northern Lincolnshire and Goole NHS Foundation Trust

author: Zannadee
title: Sub-standard service
body: My father has a history of skin cancer - in April this year he had a skin cancer removed from his scalp and was discharged back to the care of his GP Practice for dressings with instructions that if any further lesions appeared or the wound did not heal he should be referred back to the Dermatology clinic immediately rather than wait for his routine 6 month follow up. The wound is still needing be be dressed weekly and a new lesion has appeared on his scalp. My father asked the Practice Nurses several times whether he needed to see the GP to be referred back to Dermatology and was repeatedly told that everything looks OK. This week my father attended for his dressing and then asked at the practice whether he could make an appointment to see a GP - he was not asking for an appointment that day but just wanted the next available appointment. My father is elderly and has marked hearing loss so prefers to make appointments face to face as he struggles with communicating on the phone. He was informed at reception that he could not make an appointment in the surgery but had to phone to make an appointment. My father phoned this morning at 10: 10 to make an appointment, was asked to give details of why he needed to make an appointment and then was informed that a GP would phone him back today, when my father asked at what approximate time the GP would call he was informed that it would be when the GP had 'finished seeing patients'. My father has remained in the house all day waiting for a phone call from the GP which has never come. He will now have to wait until Monday and have to phone back again and presumeably go through the whole process again. I feel, as does my father, that this is unacceptably poor service from the GP practice. Whilst we understand that there may have been workload pressures for the GP would it have been too complicated to ask someone to ring my father back to explain what was going on?

author: greenmb74
title: Positive mental health experience
body: Was panicking about seeing new psychiatrist suffer anxiety and other mental health problems was put at ease by my cpn who has been at the end of the phone all through my struggles during the pandemic with distraction techniques .. have tried to take these on board feeling positive upping my medication and cpn always listens without judgement always got back to me on fone .. also realise I need to help myself .. very positive experience and can’t thank cpn enough for help which I find hard to ask for

readBy.name: North Ayrshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Hapxt48
title: An extremely positive experience
body:
A big thank you to the RHC ED, Maxillo-facial and Radiology departments!!  
I recently attended the ED at RHC Glasgow with my 6 yr old daughter after she injured her face. She has ADHD and can easily become very stressed and unco-operative but we had an extremely positive experience. From the moment we arrived all the staff were friendly and helpful and were able to put my daughter at ease. Everyone who came in to see us was extremely responsive to her needs. The nurses were so friendly and playful when doing her obs and the ED registrar and consultant came to see us very quickly. Everyone was and extremely reassuring and the calm environment really helped my daughter cope. The Max-Fax registrar came over to review my daughter immediately and arranged for an x-ray and follow up. When she was getting restless waiting for a specialist opinion she was offered an ice lolly. This was brilliant as it was just what she needed to help her cope with her x ray. I cannot thank the wonderful staff enough as this could have been a very stressful experience.

author: Rice
title: Rude behaviour and unhelpful
body: I attended my practice for an injection. I was told to just sit down when I attempted to close the clinic door, which was currently wedged open. There were no introductions in view that I had never met this member of staff before. I asked for clarity over my treatment, and despite looking at my clinical notes they were unable to provide an answer and I felt fobbed off. I asked the staff member to write my next appointment date down for me on a piece of paper to remind me, which they acted unhappy about, Upon leaving the consultation I noticed that there was a person sitting outside the room who has due to the door being open had overheard the whole consultation, so much for patient confidentiality.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

title: A&E and Ambulatory care: Great service
body:
I attended A&E and was greatly impressed by the effective service I received. There was a high number of staff, prioritisation was carried out efficiently and my investigation and treatment was very thorough.
I praise the staff who have to deal with far too many ungrateful and complaining people who never say a thank you. When I spoke to the nurses who saw me I could understand that staff work long hours and have tremendous pressure and responsibility. I could see first hand they have to deal with patients from multiple cultures and many varying languages as well as rudeness and aggression sadly from patients, some of whom have a sense of entitlement even for really relatively minor ailments. Maybe if they were paying they would be more grateful and less demanding.
I think GP surgeries really should be doing more to handle cases in the first instance. 
My experience was positive and I remain grateful for the NHS which has to operate within a way overpopulated country

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

title: Excellent practice.
body:
Contacted surgery phone call appointment arranged one hour later GP contacted me, after conversation GP asked to come to surgery on visit was examined very thoroughly and given medication all with in 2 hours , since then GP contacted me twice and shown there concern.
I feel i had first class service. Thank you to the GP.

title: Absolutely Fabulous as
body: As soon as you enter the building your met by very professional people who make you feel very relaxed no need to worry over the care you receive as it’s the best I’ve known any questions are answered in a very positive and professional way cleanliness is first class on entering theatre the surgeon will introduce himself and explain the procedure no needles no cuts no stitches no worries I shall certainly recommend to all my friends my heartfelt thanks to all

author: stonenm79
title: Blood count very low.
body:
Admitted to Causeway Hospital, Coleraine admitted to Surgical wards 1 and then 2.  
I was resident with them 6 days. I have nothing but admiration for the members of staff on both wards. Although up to 4 staff down on most days, it did not reduce the care and attention given, sometimes under great pressure from some of the patients..  
Whilst not recommending going for a holiday, I will say you could not be in better hands. I thank all of them without exception

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Amazing surgery
body:
Really grateful for the prompt and excellent service provided by this surgery.
Receptionists are always friendly and helpful whilst GP’s are very professional and knowledgeable.
I would highly recommend this surgery.

title: Just to say "Thank You"
body: I was admitted via ambulance to the A&E Department suffering from worsening SOB with pulmonary fibrosis. After several hours treatment i was transferred to a waiting ward before being admitted to the Respiratory ward. I cannot speak highly enough of the professional care i was given from admission to discharge, and would just like to say a big thank you to everyone at Poole Hospital.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Dorset NHS Foundation Trust

title: Superb
body: Quick, clean, very good and pleasant staff - an excellent part of the NHS system - (no additional comments)

title: so efficient- so helpful
body: I had a phone consultation - the receptionist was so helpful and it is clear that everyone is under pressure- I was phoned by a GP who was so helpful -including rapidly arranging my prescription thank you

title: excellent practice
body:
In spite of the all the challenges around Covid  the practice, nurses and doctors have been excellent. I've recieved good treatment on line and in person.
Sometimes I've not been sure about when and where to go for Covid test, the practice has been very helpful.

title: Excellent care
body:
I saw a GP yesterday afternoon and it was recommended that I have an urgent referral for a scan at Southmead hospital.

I had the scan at lunchtime today less than 24 hours after seeing the GP.

I am very happy with the speedy response from both Clevedon Medical Centre and Southmead hospital.

Faultless service from the NHS.

author: Alfie77
title: Colonoscopy Bridlington
body: Just wanted to thank everyone for there great care today at Bridlington hospital. The care I was given was 1st class everyone I encountered was very friendly and tried to put you at ease. You should all be very proud of your fantastic customer service.

author: Rosmy44
title: Prenatal Ultrasound
body:
My daughter attended Hairmyres Hospital ante natal for her 36 week growth scan.  
The lady who attended to us and did the scan was called Angie.  
I would just like to say how professional, helpful, considerate and informative they were. My daughter and myself were so pleased with the care we received and I am a firm believer in credit where credit is due. I think Angie is a credit to Hairmyres hospital and cannot thank her enough for her professionalism and care.

title: Outstanding Care
body:
My 4 year old daughter recently had surgery and was an inpatient on two separate occasions on the Children's Ward.
We are so grateful for the care she received and have nothing but praise for all of the staff involved in her care on the ward.

readBy.name: North Cumbria Integrated Care NHS Foundation Trust

title: Very helpful
body: I recently had a serious accident. The help I got from this surgery and the after care was so good. They checked up on me and changed my medication when necessary.

title: Gold standard care
body: Over the past month, I have had to access medical care for my elderly Father unexpectedly. Everyone I have spoken to at the surgery have gone above and beyond to help us in difficult times with such patience and compassion. From reception, the surgery pharmacist, HCA and GP. Thank you so much, the care you have shown us, it is appreciated

title: Great Hospital
body: I've had cataracts in both eyes treated at SpaMedica in Wolverhampton. The staff were very friendly and reassuring and the whole experience was second to none. The surgery went well and I now have great vision in both eyes. The whole process took less than 2 hours on both occasions.A big thank you to all the staff at SpaMedica Wolverhampton

title: Good GP Practice
body:
Good GP surgery! All staff are professional and caring and the reception staff are friendly and helpful whether it be over the phone or face to face. 
E consultations and phone consultations seem to work well and the practice uses the GP App for ordering prescriptions etc. Despite the events of 2020 we have had no issues accessing the GP or the Practice Nurse where necessary and have received good clinical care.
The premises are always clean and welcoming and parking in near by roads not a problem.

title: Lovely staff
body: As always, staff are helpful and cheerful! Throughout the pandemic, they have never failed the patients, they are friendly but professional! Well done to you all, from receptionists to doctors!

title: Amazing care and consideration!
body: The Emergency Practitioner i saw today was amazing. He was very reassuring and put me at ease straight away. He reminded me of everything that makes our NHS so great. He was the embodiment of what someone working in our healthcare should look like. I could see that this was his vocation and calling to look after and care for others. Thank you for such a positive experience at Mandeville today.

author: Scottish Lass
title: My hospital experience when I gave birth
body:
I gave birth at Raigmore Hospital in Inverness on 08. 08. 2021. I can't fault the two midwifes and care team who helped me deliver my child. They were amazing! How ever when I was moved onto the ward I felt like I was abandoned from then on when it came to me needing help to breast feed.  
I understand that the hospital are very short staffed and I always new breast feeding was going to be hard. But I didn't realise how hard it would be, my child struggled to latch on and the midwifes would aways say buzz if you need help. I always did buzz as she wouldn't latch on or if she did only for a few seconds. The other mums on the ward were needy and were always buzzing for things. How ever I was more than happy to do stuff myself and I only ever buzzed when I needed help with her to latch on.  
Many times I had to wait long periods of time before someone would help me including a time where it was 45 minutes. By that time my child was so hungry and crying that it made me cry and stress out. I hated that I couldn't feed her and felt awful knowing that she was upset and I couldn't do anything but wait for help. I am a first time mum and I needed help and support and I didn't feel I got that.  
My child had really bad jaundice and I had to stay in hospital for 3. 5 days. Which were stressful and tough for me. It was clear I was really struggling to breast feed so a midwife suggested that I express my milk as she knew how much I wanted my child to have breast milk and I didn't want to use formula. A couple of the midwifes supported me with my decision to try this including a student midwife from Robert Gordon University who I absolutely loved as she was amazing! She is a going to be a brilliant midwife and it was her who made what little good experience of my hospital stay good.  
The other midwifes didn't support me and I felt like I was a bad person for wanting to express. I was at this point still trying to breast feed. I was so tired as I wasn't sleeping. After speaking to the midwife who was there when I gave birth, I had the courage to tell the other midwifes that it was my decision to express my milk to give to my child and that I had to as my child wasn't getting from me. Since expressing my milk I was slowly building up the amount, occasionally I had to top up with formula as I wasn't making enough milk for my child. I had a good rhythm. On the day of me being discharged I had to wait 5 hrs for my discharge letter, everyone else was leaving and I was the only one left. Again I understand that the hospital are short staffed. But I needed to get home so my midwife could drop off express pump so I could continue to express my milk.  
Unfortunately due to waiting so long for my discharge letter, I didn't get home till 6. 30pm which meant I didn't get the pump till the next day. I couldn't express for over 12 hours which then made what little milk supply I had stop. I had to use formula feeding over night to feed her as I was still struggling to breast feed her. This upset me as I didn't want to use formula.  
After 6 stressful and upsetting days I had to accept that I couldn't breast feed, which was extremely hard for me to accept. I still express milk but I don't make enough to feed her so I have to top up using formula. I feel if I got the support I needed I would have been able to breast feed. I feel let down and my hospital experience was very tough and stressful for me.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Friendly hard working staff
body:
Staff were fantastic, first time staying on (Levington) ward overnight and can’t sing their praises enough. helpful, friendly, efficient and i have no hesitation in going back or recommending them. Special shout out to the nurse that went the extra mile for me when i was discharged via patient transport.
My surgeon and his team have always been fantastic so this experience was icing on the cake. Thank-you NHS staff- for all that you do, its not just a job- it’s the care that's taken in carrying it out so well whilst working with what you have.

readBy.name: East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent Service Again
body: My wife phoned and got through to speak to a very helpful receptionist who sent her a link on her mobile phone to upload some information. Had a call back within an hour to say Doctor had looked at the details and would like her to go into the surgery that afternoon. Saw a Doctor on time who was kind and supportive and arranged a referral to a Specialist. Very good service with everything sorted on the day. Our thanks to the team.

title: Always there for me
body: In spite of the constraints created by the pandemic, the surgery has done everything in its power to respond to and care for its patients. If you use the system of the econsultation, or book a telephone appointment, you will certainly be looked after appropriately. The receptionists are are cheerful, friendly and professional, the nurses are great. Love this practice!

title: Doing well.
body: I have reason to visit the surgery every 2 weeks, and was dubious about the merger (previously being Worthen). I do see the same GP each time and cannot fault him, he has been excellent with my care. There were a few niggles with prescriptions to start but I think we are getting it sorted now! The whole NHS is still under tremendous pressure and I think people need to remember this at times.

title: Kind & Caring
body: My husband received the most wonderful care prior to passing away in July. All the staff were absolutely marvellous. I can't thank them enough.

title: Professional care
body: Eye appointment. Quick referral, easy appointment and location. Lovely receptionist and really clear optometrist who explained everything

title: Rosa parks ward
body: I would just like to congratulate all the staff on the Rosa Parks ward. My son was admitted for a short period of time and the care he received from all the staff was absolutely amazing. The staff were so hardworking, polite, respectful, caring, understanding and most of all selfless. Nothing was too much for them. They really made my son feel comfortable and helped him with all his treatment. Thank you so much Rosa Parks staff we are truly grateful for all your kindness and hardwork.

readBy.name: South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great first experience at this practice
body: Appointment was spot on. Relatively easy to get. Good advice and resulting action. I would recommend the service.

title: Excellent care and treatment
body: I cannot recommend highly enough. Surgeon and nurses are fabulous and made a special effort to make me feel cared for. They obviously enjoy their work and take great pride in it. Very professional. A huge thank you.

title: Excellent Service
body: This is a fabulous service in my local community. I was seen exactly at the time of my appointment and was greeted by a friendly member of staff. I felt at ease for my tests and in the consultation and everything was explained clearly to me. I felt safe and very well looked after. I feel so lucky to have this ophthalmic service so close to home as it most definitely reduced my stress levels by going to a familiar location. The consultant was just lovely and I feel safe under his watch! Thank you for providing such a welcoming and valuable service. I am very grateful.

title: Incredible staff
body: Went into labour at RHCH the two midwives looking after me, my partner and our new born baby were incredible one of them only being a first year student who was beyond knowledgeable and very informative with everything that was happening throughout. The doctor that had to come and help me was absolutely amazing. Couldn’t thank the staff enough.

author: Karen mc k
title: Two broken wrists
body:
I fell over my daughter’s suitcase  
Broke both wrists  
Had exceptional care from the following members of staff in the fracture clinic RVH  
Mr Diamond  
Mr Mullan  
Stella  
Paul  
Julie  
Kaiya  
Catherine  
Anne  
Merin  
Dr Rebecca  
Suzanna  
Jaquie  
And Charlotte in ward 4B  
So kind, attentive, caring and thoughtful  
I am truly grateful and humbled  
Today the saga continues with Shannon in the physio and Christine who assessed me exceptional in every way . Thank you

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

title: Amazing practice
body: I moved to this practice 6/7 year’s ago amd I absolutely love it . The team is absolutely amazing and kind hearted . Every time I speak to the doctors whether its on the phone or in person they always listen . I love my gp practice and wouldnt go anywhere else

author: wezenww66
title: Community Nursing
body:
For Community Nurse Helen  
She was a sociable and approachable nurse, who helped my son, however I felt the discharge process was a but rushed, but understand how busy nurses are.

title: Light therapy Basford
body: i think that the location is very close to me and i have been treated with respect by the staff. the waiting times are really good. i have never had to wait longer than 10 minutes.

title: Great Practice
body:
I recently gave birth to a beautiful baby boy and needed to find a GP Surgery nearer to home. After having the same GP since i was born I was very nervous and apprehensive re changing. I have to say the practice manager is the reason I chose this surgery she gave me full confidence and was extremely helpful on helping me with paperwork etc to make the change and has been so supportive with ensuring myself and my baby have always been provided the care we need.
Great Practice and the staff are a credit to this place from reception to the lovely nurse you have. Keep up the great service and thank you.

title: Really appreciate good service
body:
In the last year l can’t fault the practice. 
Doctors and receptionists have been so helpful each time I’ve called. 
Thank you

title: Fantastic Experience
body: Having been recently diagnosed with a cyst in my neck the service and compassion I have received from the practice has been excellent. Yesterday I had to go for my pre-assessment check at the hospital where part of the process is to take some bloods for pathology ahead of my surgery. The hospitals nurse, senior nurse and nurse practitioner/trainer could not get any blood out of me, in the end I was left feeling like a pub dart board. I told them I would go to my local GP and get it done. Now I am needle phobic at the best of times, so the day so far was not leaving me happy. Arrived at the practice, explained what had happened and was immediately ushered in to the nurses room (Cat), and by the time I had started explaining what had happened she had 5 full vials of blood. Less than 30secs. I can't recommend this practice enough for their compassion and professionalism. Thanks Cat and team, really appreciate your help yesterday and putting me at ease. You are a star!

title: Great Practice
body:
Lancaster Gate Medical Centre has been my local GP Surgery for over 20 years. As I have ongoing sickness issues, I have regular contact with the surgery.

I have always found the level of service from the staff, particularly the reception staff, to be fast, efficient, helpful and excellent. They are very professional, friendly, kind, patient, and in my experience over the years go the extra mile, even recently, due to covid, where times have been extremely extra tough on them all. 

My doctors and nurses are fantastic, very thorough, empathetic and caring and even though it's a very busy surgery they always seem to have time for me and I never feel rushed and I feel very well looked after. 

I feel very fortunate and grateful to have Lancaster Gate Medical Centre as my local GP Surgery. A big, big heartfelt and grateful thanks to all staff.

title: The best GP practice
body: From the receptionist always helpful and prompt, doctor thorough and professional, to the nurse practitioner who is knowledgeable and compassionate. By far the best GP practice! Thank you

title: Excellent Practice
body:
Easy to book online and quick responses. The surgery has excellent doctors and the opportunity to do phone consultations which saves time being booked off work.
The online 'get help with anything' makes it less embarrassing to talk about problems and the responses are always very quick and helpful and I have been treated with respect.

title: Very caring
body:
I was referred for physio as injured my knee. The physiotherapist was excellent. Answered all my questions, very thorough and caring. Gave me follow up
Appointment after diagnosing my problem.

title: Kind, caring, and professional
body: Having had a bad colonoscopy experience at a different hospital a few years ago I was dreading attending a 3 year follow-up colonoscopy yesterday. I'd decided to try to change to Lymington hospital - primarily because of much easier parking - a while back, and this was very easy to do. Yes, on arrival parking was a doddle, but the whole procedure from start to finish was absolutely brilliant. I won't pretend that the colonoscopy was totally painless but the pain was manageable because of the care of both surgeon and nurses, who listened to me and acted accordingly in terms of pain control and kind reassurances. Luckily nothing detrimental was found, but if ever I have to have another colonoscopy I will make sure that it's at Lymington. Thank you to all involved.

title: Absolutely amazing practice
body: They are faultless, cannnot recommend them highly enough, everyone from the reception staff to the nurses and doctor are amazing

title: Wonderful practice
body: I cannot recommend BRMC enough. I have been a patient here for 4 years, everything about the patient experience from reception to the doctors and nurses is outstanding. They handled appointments during the pandemic fantastically. Reception are responsive by both phone and email. Nothing is too much trouble for them. I've never had such fantastic GP care.

title: Fast Service
body: I woke up with an itchy rash. I thought I needed to get it checked out, so I visited the Phoenix Health Centre. I was seen by a healthcare professional within 10 minutes then had to wait for a nurse. I saw the nurse and was diagnosed within half an hour of arriving. I couldn't ask for any better service!

title: Miles ahead of the rest
body: The Doctors, nurses and the reception are all brilliant, helpful and are receptive to health issue you have. The doctors give time and space to listen to you and would ask for further tests to understand better your health issue and would always involve you the treatment plan they think is appropriate for you

title: Amazing GP Practice
body: Escrick surgery is outstanding. The doctors are consistently caring, attentive and follow up on issues. They care for my whole family and the staff are excellent also. Always patient and responsive with a great pharmacy service on site.

title: Decompression and Microdiscectomy
body:
L5/S1 Decompression and Microdiscetomy
Really mixed feelings about this place and the whole experience. Firstly when I went for my pre op etc I was told that I needed to stop taking certain meds 7 days before my operation. This was 6 days before my operation, luckily I had guessed this myself and stopped taking them... Not a great confidence boost as any blood thinners could have caused complications. On the day of the op I arrived and was shown to my room I would be staying in during my stay. Kudos on trying to freshen the place up but the strong smell of paint/gloss definately didn't go down too well and makes not drinking a bit more difficult when it's burning you to breathe. I understand that my admission time is not the time of my operation but over 4 hours later from being admitted to going for surgery.... Was thirsty work. Being told to drink plenty of fluid leading upto the op but then going 5 hours without a sip of water was harsh... Surely they knew roughly when I would be going to theatre and could change the time for my last water intake so I could have a drink to sooth the burn from the gloss. The op I think went well, not sure as I was sleeping.... But then coming round I was in agony and although I was telling them I was in pain and the pain was in my back and legs I was told "yes you had surgery on your back". This is the second time I have had this operation and knew this pain wasn't normal, I literally had to writhe in pain whilst trying to explain what was wrong a number of times before I was given any pain relief even though it was clear I was having bad muscle spasms in my legs and back causing the pain. On return to my room I was left until approx 8pm when I had to ask for somerhing to eat as it had been over 24 hours since I had eaten. Now don't get me wrong.... The food was dam nice... Just a shame I had to ask for it almost 2 hours afyer coming out of surgery. Then there was the room, the general area was clean and tidy but closer inspection showed a different story. And the bathroom was pretty dam drubby. There was tape over the seat saying "sanitised for your protection" or similar.... I'd day this same tape had been on there for a while, it was just grubby everywhere and not what I'd expect from a hospital.

As for the team, couldn't really fault them. All were pretty good. 
Final point is that I was given a pack to take to my doctors for a dressing change but I was sent home in the same dressing that was applied after surgery, nobody checked my wound on discharge or changed the dressing that is covered in dry blood due to leakage or some sorts (so much so it bled through onto the bed sheets). Last time I had this op my wound was checked and dressing changed to a waterproof one so thst I could at least shower, right now I've gone 5 days with baby wipe "showers" and have had to book into my doctors earlier than asked so that I can get this disgusting dressing off and for them to check my wound.

author: reddevilsgo1
title: Great Practice Manager
body: I have received excellent help from the Practice manager which has helped enormously with a situation and it is appreciated.

author: larz51
title: Feeling left in the dark
body:
I have received a letter this morning from the Urology department as I was supposed to be having a face to face appointment with Mr Moody, this has now been delayed.  
I feel uninformed about what's actually going on, I also had a barium x-ray back in June and still have had no results from that and its nearly 2 & half months down the line.I feel like nobody seems to care and I'm sorry I think its completely unacceptable. I appreciate there are delays due to covid but surely someone could pick up the phone and help make the patients feel more informed. A simply apology and explanation wouldn't go a miss. I feel like there is a lack of communication between the services and the patient and would like to feel more informed.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Eimeargallogly
title: Daughters birth
body:
We would like to say a heartfelt thank you to the amazing midwives in SWAH, western trust, NI, who safely brought baby Aoife into the world, Tracey and Anne-marie.  
Tracey you made us feel so safe, advocated for Aoife and I when I couldn't and provided plenty of laughs to replace the tears.  
Anne-Marie thank you for all your kindness and reassurance.  
To the maternity ward staff, thank you for all your patience and comfort.  
You girls are all a credit to the trust and to your profession, we are so lucky to have you all help us being our babies into the world.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: jupitergd37
title: Amazing Help in a time of need
body:
Emma - Community Nurse  
Emma has been absolutely amazing, and wish she was still our community nurse. She has helped and supported both myself and my sister (Client), and she has been an absolute rock during a very difficult time.  
Emma has always been very professional and I always knew that I could ring her and she would help and sort out things that needed to be done in a timely manner.  
She was absolutely amazing and cannot find any fault in how she cared for my sister.

author: Shelly01
title: I would recommend the services I came for.
body:
I visited the Fern Centre for the first time today. It has a very bright and inviting reception area on entry. I especially like the level which was accessible and near to some parking spaces. It could benefit from more parking in the immediate vicinity because it's a long walk to the main car park with mobility difficulties. 
I would recommend the the services I came for.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Supermum
title: Getting work
body:
I have been out of work for about a year or so, then I was told about an employment advisor at manor road. I was not sure as even though I wanted to work, I lost a lot of confidence and was let go at last job due to my illness and time off. When I met Debby initially at manor road she was super friendly, and at first thought this was not real, but after about 2 sessions I realised she is genuine and down to earth, and really is dedicated to trying to help you.  
She helped me to believe I could succeed, but deep down I am not sure I believed it ..at the time I was up and down, but on the down days she would be present and put no pressure on me, just listen when I was stressing. Debby did not try to fix it which is what I needed, and when I started to feel better she did not rush me, even though I think she gets marked on getting people work she put me first.  
My partner and kids liked her too. She has an amazing sense of humor, I wish I had met her years ago I am sure it would have helped me, I wanted to write to tell others if they think they can't give Debby a call and I can guarantee she will help and she never judges which I love.  
Debby got me not one but 3 jobs to work round my kids, and it is working great, I will miss our chats but I am sure others needs this kind of help and I am sorted. Debby will do anything to help you she went to the employer and even got questions of the interview and wrote answers for me. She helped me see my job (not just the paid ones) but my role as a mum comes with a skill set. She is fab and NHS are lucky to have her.

author: Dollycreek
title: It is a lovely place very clean well organised
body: I am happy to give a review of Torrington Day Treatment Unit. I have never been to the hospital before, I had 2 infusions there and I found it so much better than the Chemotherapy Unit at Barnstaple. It is a lovely place very clean well organised and staff are very friendly and helpful, couldn't do enough for their patients. It is a god send for people who live locally and find travelling to Barnstaple difficult. I recommend it to anyone, especially local people like me I would certainly use anytime.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Sandy699
title: Torrington is so convenient
body: I live in Winkleigh and being able to attend Torrington is so convenient as it is so much closer to home. The nurses are extremely friendly and the service I have is much more intimate and holistic here. Please keep it open.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: NickyW99
title: Small cottage hospitals are so important to the local community.
body: Small cottage hospitals are so important to the local community and in support of the larger hospitals to relieve pressure. Coming here today meant I only had to travel 6 miles and seen within time upon arrival. The standard of care is superb & the staff are friendly & can take time to give a higher level of personal care. The local community benefit because of the nearness of inpatients to their homes & for visiting. The larger hospitals benefit because these smaller hospitals can offer essential treatments which in turn relieves pressure on waiting lists for routine appointments. They also take up the middle ground between GP practice and a large hospital for minor injuries,  A & E , etc. These small hospitals will become more and more essential going forward for the services they provide & they must remain open.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: julikenn
title: Prostate operation
body: I had a transurethral resection of prostate at Altnagelvin Hospital, Londonderry. I opted for a general anaesthetic. I was cared for superbly from entering the building to leaving it later as a completed day case.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: leoyd39
title: Bowel screening programme
body:
In April this year I carried out the biannual home bowel screening test which I have been doing from the age of sixty. It skipped a year last year presumably because of the Covid situation throughout 2020.  
The test showed that further examination was required and as a result I received an initial assessment by way of telephone call from Amanda at the Gemini suite located at the NDDH. As a result an appointment was made for me to attend at NDDH for a colonoscopy examination and as a result of the examination a large polyp was removed from my bowel. The biopsy result showed the poly had high risk cells present.  
As a result I attended the Gemini suite for a follow up colonoscopy. Three biopsy samples were taken from around the polyp removal site for examination and I am very pleased and relieved to say the results have proved to be negative.  
I wish to thank Dr Davis and all the team at the Gemini suit, Cara, Tim, Rachel and Emma for their very caring and professional manner. I'm do apologise that I can't remember the names of all involved, the whole team are excellent.  
I was totally placed at ease by all and at the end of the procedures a lovely cup of tea from suite manager Cara before discharge.  
It saddens me that the NHS comes under so much criticism at times especially from the press. The speed at which the NHS worked for me in this situation was astounding and clearly the Bowel Screening programme without doubt saved me from a more serious situation in the future!  
Finally a really big thank you to Amanda for all her telephone communications and help on the procedure days, she is a most professional, caring and comforting nurse.  
A massive thank you to the whole team at the NDDH Gemini suite.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Joanncad
title: Care & understanding
body:
I attended the day surgery to have SI joint injection in my back  
The whole team in day surgery from the nursing staff to the consultant dealing with me we're all fantastic! ! I cannot fault the care & understanding from them all. I have been under the care of the pain clinic for a number of years & I've had numerous treatments in day surgery, and on all of my visits, I cannot fault anything.  
Thank you all very much for making my stay with you as pleasant as possible

readBy.name: Sheffield Hallam University, faculty of health & wellbeing
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

links.id: degenerative disc disease with disc protrusions

author: DavidA21
title: Cancelled procedure
body: I am utterly shocked and feel completely discriminated against. I had a procedure booked in the Gilbert Bain for an endoscope. I was called by a staff member and told, I felt in a mocking manner, that they had found out that I had been off the island, and would have my procedure cancelled due to this. The government website does not state that we can not move around freely, basically they tell us that we cant visit a pub, restaurant, or leave the island by ferry and we need to be socially distanced at 2 metres apart. I did all of the above but I went on the ferry remaining in my cabin etc. Who decides whether or not I can travel inter island on a ferry to Yell for example but cannot go to Aberdeen. They told me within Shetland on a ferry would be okay but not to the mainland. We are past level zero and this madness needs to end. I pay my national insurance for my care in the NHS and my care is not being upheld due to a policy that does not go along with basic government guidelines.

author: Hester Ectomy
title: Pelvic Ultrasound
body:
The sonographer pushed very hard on my pelvic area with the wand. I have had several pelvic ultrasounds before - I am 48 and never been in very good health. It was not just uncomfortable, it was VERY painful.  
The sonographer did not say sorry I'll try to be more gentle, in fact the choice I was given was to carry on the same, or stop. I said I wanted to find the cause of the ovarian pain I was experiencing. They continued to push extremely hard into me. I gritted my teeth, it was obvious I was in pain. I asked for their name, since I know full well pushing so hard is not necessary. The sonographer's name badge was flipped over so I could not see.  
Eventually they said they would use the vaginal wand, so everything was set up for that, and it was much easier once inserted. The sonographers aim for inserting it was pretty poor though and to say that was ham fisted would be a kindness. Once it was in, it did not hurt.  
I am concerned that this person is causing pain to patients. Overall the procedure felt abusive.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: aprilqh87
title: Covid-19 vaccine in pregnancy
body: I am 33 weeks pregnant and decided to get the Covid-19 vaccine to protect me and my baby Given the increasing numbers of incidents of Covid where I am and the opening up of many services which my family uses. I had been undecided for a while and was nervous about getting the vaccine but the midwife who administered the vaccine couldn’t have been more reassuring. She was warm and friendly and provided me with valuable information. I was also fast-tracked to the top of a very long queue which I appreciate being quite heavily pregnant. I came away feeling I had done exactly the right thing for me, my baby and my peace of mind. Thank you

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: HazelS21
title: First class care
body: I was admitted as an emergency to ERI and due to bed shortages was placed in day surgery. The nursing staff were truly amazing from start to finish although Catriona & Fiona (night shift) deserve a special mention.

author: U/0232
title: Our experience with hospital mental health
body:
I am aware of the increased spending and focus on suicide prevention from the Scottish government. Our experience regarding hospital mental health aftercare is far removed from the government rhetoric.  
My daughter made another attempt on her life. She was looked after well in A&E and kept in overnight. I was assured that she would not be discharged from hospital without speaking to a mental health professional. Once again, I receive a call from my daughter saying a doctor has discharged her "as fit to walk" this morning. She had no visit from mental health. This is not the first time that she has been discharged after a suicide attempt without input from mental health services. I have called the Royal Edinburgh hospital today and they have no note of my daughter's situation. Where is the joined-up thinking? Where is the link up/communication between services? As her family, we have to cope with our daughter not wanting to live. On top of this, she is dismissed from hospital with no added commitment of support, follow up or even compassion for an ill and visibly troubled young person.  
I am asking for your help in changing this - that all hospitalized suicide attempts should never be discharged without contact with a mental health professional.

readBy.name: Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: Pearla
title: Track and Trace
body: I was contacted by Nicky from Greater Glasgow and Clyde Track and Trace following a positive Covid test. The service was excellent very clear questions and instructions about the process and ongoing advice. After hearing negative stories from the media I was unsure about what to expect. All round excellent service thank you

author: relative63
title: A&E attendance
body: Attended A&E due to my son becoming unwell on a trip away. I phoned ahead to ensure that the hospital was appropriate for paediatrics, and was assured that it was. Waited over 1 to see the triage nurse. The staff member didn’t introduce themself to either myself or my son, and began to check observations - again without speaking to him. I questioned if the waiting time on the board outside was accurate- it had said 5 hours when I first got there, and then changed to 6. 5 hrs. The triage nurse simply laughed and said it probably was. I appreciate that this seemed like a very busy department, and I am also aware that they are under great stress at the moment. However, these are simple manners which cost nothing. I decided to drive back home to our nearest hospital where we were triaged, treated, discussed with the surgical team and discharged with antibiotics within 1 hour.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: gruffthree
title: My sister's care
body:
In April this year my sister developed a psychosis, she was 59 years old. After some close care from the crisis mental health team she was eventually admitted to in patient psychiatric care in May.  
Considering the Covid status both locally and in the hospital, her care and management was very good overall. Whilst in hospital it became apparent that her house was not currently habitable - she is a hoarder and there was no clear sleeping facility and no cooking options. This was identified by the OT who was involved in assessing her. And whilst her psychosis was abating there were further issues becoming apparent i.e. she had some abnormalities on her CT scan of her brain and some clear cognitive impairment.  
She has been referred for further assessment by a psychiatrist with expertise in dementia in the young. To my knowledge, the ward staff referred her to social work in July in preparation for her going home. There was a patient who tested positive for Covid that week and so in patients were confined to their room. This not being ideal conditions for people recovering from psychiatric disorders, I was asked if I could accommodate her once she had completed her period of self isolation. I agreed to this for a period of 4 weeks reckoning that this would be enough time for social work to get in touch regarding her flat and for the further referral to investigate her cognitive impairment.  
That discharge was 4 weeks ago. Since that time both the crisis team and the discharge team have been in regular touch to ask about her mood and mental state, both of which are good but there has been no contact from anywhere else.  
I have spent the last 6 weeks mostly by myself trying to make progress with emptying her flat and I am exhausted. She is staying with me and my husband and daughter, and we are doing our best to accommodate her but we need help. I have tried emailing the local dementia resource centre, but got no response. She is so clearly impaired but I have no way of helping her to progress towards getting home without help. The help required cannot be identified until she has a full assessment.  
So having had good emergency care for her organic psychosis, she is now not getting the support and assessment she needs to allow her to live as full a life as she can. And I have no indication of when we can expect to hear anything.

author: Redhead66
title: Pain management
body: I waited 3 years to get an appointment with the pain clinic. When I attended the person I saw actually asked me why I was there even though I had been referred from another consultant in the hospital. They knew nothing about what had happened to me. When I was asked a question and I tried to reply they talked over the top of me. I was there 5 minutes, if even that and was told there’s nothing they can do for me I just have to live with the pain. I was disgusted at the way I was just dismissed after waiting all those years. Their manner was nothing else but rude and abrupt and to not even be aware of any background is just inexcusable.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Cat72
title: Lack of care and compassion
body: Early hours of this morning my elderly father fell and was left lying on the cold floor for over 5 hours with my frail mother. The wait on the ambulance is understandable and I appreciate how busy they are. The problem is that the ambulance crew had spoken on the phone to a Doctor from Monklands Hospital who had explained that the hospital was busy and they were struggling for beds and they don’t want him spreading covid to other patients, as my father caught covid last week (already had both vaccines). My fathers blood pressure was very low, he had hit his head during the fall (he had already fallen earlier in the week) and this time he sustained a head injury and could not feel his legs and was dizzy! ! I did not know any of this had happened until later this morning and was very upset and disgusted at the disregard for his safety, lack of care & compassion, lack of person centred, quality and equality of care from the Doctor who was calling from Monklands. Both my parents were scared, felt alone and abandoned. No one had checked his pupil size or reaction time/ neurological observations. He also had weakness in both legs. The Doctor at the other end of the telephone had not examined him before giving out advice and did not have any information about his neurological observations or action regarding his blood pressure. Also, despite my mother telling NHS 24 that my father had covid, it apparently had not been passed on to the ambulance crew. The ambulance crew using their good judgement were going to take my father to hospital for a proper examination and investigations. However, were advised not to by the Doctor from Monklands because he had covid and they were short on beds.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Starhash
title: ENT appointment
body: I was brought in for an urgent ent appointment at altnagelvin hospital. I was nervous and stressed as I have been experiencing symptoms for quite a while. Mairead was amazing and reassured me and took time to explain what the tests were for and what would happen next, despite how busy they were. She was so kind, compassionate and professional and needs to be recognised.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: MoDubh
title: Experience of an Elderly friend
body:
Recently I took an elderly friend to A&E as she was experiencing pain and several other symptoms following a dislocated shoulder. She had already been in contact with a medical person a few days previously who advised her to go to A&E had things not improved.  
When booking in she was asked if she needed someone with her which she did not. When she came out of A&E and related her experience to me I was shocked and angry that a person of her age could be treated in the way she had been. Her care lacked compassion and dignity. The nurse who dealt with her treated her in a totally unprofessional and unsympathetic manner with her relating a personal experience and the tone used. My friend was sent out of hospital upset and angry, was given no extra pain relief but was provided with contradictory advice from that given at the fracture clinic. As I have already said the care she received lacked dignity, compassion and most importantly of all, professionalism and I would hope that this is not the normal treatment that patients receive.

author: Kate87
title: So kind and patient
body: Thank you to the ED staff who treated my son at the weekend. They were so busy but took the time to reassure both him and me and to make sure he got the treatment required! A special thanks to the triage nurse Catriona and the student nurse Aine for being so kind and patient with a very frightened little boy! 💙

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust
